docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Real-world usage examples for PraisonAIWP.

docs.title: Publish a Blog Post
docs.text:
praisonaiwp create "10 Tips for Productivity" \
  --content "$(cat article.html)" \
  --category "Lifestyle" \
  --tags "productivity,tips,work" \
  --status publish \
  --featured-image cover.jpg

docs.title: Batch Update Posts
docs.text:
# Update all drafts to pending review
for id in $(praisonaiwp list --status draft --field ID --format csv); do
  praisonaiwp update $id --post-status pending
done

docs.title: Schedule Posts
docs.text:
praisonaiwp create "Future Post" \
  --content "<p>Coming soon!</p>" \
  --status future \
  --date "2024-12-25 09:00:00"

docs.title: Generate and Publish
docs.text:
# Generate content
content=$(praisonaiwp ai generate "Write a 500-word article about renewable energy")

# Create post with generated content
praisonaiwp create "Renewable Energy Guide" \
  --content "$content" \
  --category "Environment" \
  --status draft

docs.title: Find Duplicates Before Publishing
docs.text:
# Check for similar content
praisonaiwp duplicate check "My new article title and content..."

docs.title: Sync Content Between Sites
docs.text:
# Export from production
praisonaiwp --server production export --type post --output posts.xml

# Import to staging
praisonaiwp --server staging import posts.xml

docs.title: Compare Sites
docs.text:
# List plugins on both
echo "=== Production ===" && praisonaiwp --server production plugin list
echo "=== Staging ===" && praisonaiwp --server staging plugin list

docs.title: Backup Before Changes
docs.text:
# Create backup
praisonaiwp backup create --name "pre-migration-$(date +%Y%m%d)"

# Make changes
praisonaiwp search-replace "http://old-domain.com" "https://new-domain.com" --dry-run

# If looks good, run for real
praisonaiwp search-replace "http://old-domain.com" "https://new-domain.com"

docs.title: Domain Migration
docs.text:
# Search and replace URLs
praisonaiwp search-replace "https://staging.example.com" "https://example.com" \
  --all-tables \
  --precise

# Flush cache
praisonaiwp cache flush

# Flush rewrite rules
praisonaiwp rewrite flush

docs.title: Get Post Data
docs.text:
# Get post as JSON
post=$(praisonaiwp --json list --include 123)
title=$(echo "$post" | jq -r '.[0].post_title')
echo "Title: $title"

docs.title: Automation Script
docs.text:
import subprocess
import json

def get_posts(status="publish", limit=10):
    result = subprocess.run(
        ["praisonaiwp", "--json", "list", f"--status={status}", f"--limit={limit}"],
        capture_output=True,
        text=True
    )
    return json.loads(result.stdout)

posts = get_posts()
for post in posts:
    print(f"{post['ID']}: {post['post_title']}")

docs.title: Deploy and Verify
docs.text:
# After deploying WordPress to K8s
praisonaiwp --server my-k8s-site help

# Create test post
praisonaiwp --server my-k8s-site create "Test Post" \
  --content "<p>Deployment test</p>" \
  --status draft

docs.title: Check Site Health
docs.text:
# Core version
praisonaiwp --server my-k8s-site core version

# Plugin status
praisonaiwp --server my-k8s-site plugin list --status active

# Database status
praisonaiwp --server my-k8s-site db check

docs.title: Start MCP Server
docs.text:
# For AI tool integration (e.g., Claude)
praisonaiwp mcp serve

docs.title: Create Posts
docs.text: Create WordPress posts with automatic Gutenberg block conversion.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text: praisonaiwp create "Post Title" --content "<p>Post content here</p>"

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --content TEXT Post content (HTML auto-converts to Gutenberg) --status STATUS Post status: draft, publish, pending, private --type TYPE Post type: post, page, or custom type --category NAME Category name or ID --tags TAGS Comma-separated tags --author USER Author username or ID --date DATE Publish date (YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS) --excerpt TEXT Post excerpt --featured-image PATH Set featured image from local file --no-block-conversion Skip HTML to Gutenberg conversion

docs.title: Create and Publish
docs.text:
praisonaiwp create "My Article" \
  --content "<h2>Introduction</h2><p>Welcome to my article.</p>" \
  --status publish \
  --category "Technology"

docs.title: Create a Page
docs.text:
praisonaiwp create "About Us" \
  --content "<p>About our company...</p>" \
  --type page \
  --status publish

docs.title: Create with Tags and Category
docs.text:
praisonaiwp create "AI News" \
  --content "<p>Latest AI developments...</p>" \
  --category "News" \
  --tags "ai,machine-learning,technology" \
  --status publish

docs.title: Create Draft for Later
docs.text:
praisonaiwp create "Draft Post" \
  --content "<p>Work in progress...</p>" \
  --status draft

docs.title: With Featured Image
docs.text:
praisonaiwp create "Photo Post" \
  --content "<p>Check out this photo!</p>" \
  --featured-image /path/to/image.jpg \
  --status publish

docs.title: Gutenberg Block Format
docs.text:
HTML is automatically converted to Gutenberg blocks:

HTML Gutenberg Block <p>text</p> <!-- wp:paragraph --> <h2>text</h2> <!-- wp:heading --> <ul><li>item</li></ul> <!-- wp:list --> <pre>code</pre> <!-- wp:code --> <blockquote>text</blockquote> <!-- wp:quote --> <table>...</table> <!-- wp:table -->

docs.title: Raw Gutenberg Blocks
docs.text:
Skip conversion with --no-block-conversion:

praisonaiwp create "Block Post" \
  --no-block-conversion \
  --content '<!-- wp:paragraph --><p>Raw block</p><!-- /wp:paragraph -->'

praisonaiwp --json create "Post" --content "<p>Hello</p>"

Returns:

  "success": true,
  "post_id": 123,
  "url": "https://example.com/post/"
}

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: PraisonAIWP uses a YAML configuration file to manage server connections.

docs.title: Configuration File Location
docs.text: ~/.praisonaiwp/config.yaml

docs.title: Initialize Configuration
docs.text: praisonaiwp init

docs.title: Configuration Structure
docs.text:
default_server: my-server
version: '2.0'

servers:
  my-server:
    # Website URL (for URL routing)
    website: https://example.com
    description: "My WordPress site"

    # SSH connection
    hostname: example.com
    username: admin
    key_file: ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
    port: 22

    # WordPress paths
    wp_path: /var/www/wordpress
    php_bin: /usr/bin/php
    wp_cli: /usr/local/bin/wp

settings:
  auto_backup: true
  auto_route: true
  log_level: INFO
  parallel_threshold: 10
  parallel_workers: 10
  retry_attempts: 3
  ssh_timeout: 30

docs.title: SSH Transport (Default)
docs.text: Option Required Description hostname Yes Server hostname or IP username No SSH username (uses SSH config if not set) key_file No Path to SSH private key port No SSH port (default: 22) ssh_host No SSH config host alias wp_path Yes WordPress installation path php_bin No PHP binary path (default: php) wp_cli No WP-CLI path (default: /usr/local/bin/wp)

docs.title: Kubernetes Transport
docs.text:
See Kubernetes Setup for detailed instructions.

servers:
  my-k8s-site:
    transport: kubernetes
    pod_selector: app=wordpress
    namespace: default
    container: wordpress
    wp_path: /var/www/html
    php_bin: /usr/local/bin/php
    wp_cli: wp

docs.title: Multiple Servers
docs.text:
servers:
  production:
    website: https://example.com
    hostname: prod.example.com
    wp_path: /var/www/wordpress

  staging:
    website: https://staging.example.com
    hostname: staging.example.com
    wp_path: /var/www/wordpress

  local:
    website: http://localhost:8080
    ssh_host: local-wp
    wp_path: /var/www/html

docs.title: Using Different Servers
docs.text:
# Use default server
praisonaiwp list

# Use specific server
praisonaiwp --server staging list

# Or specify by URL
praisonaiwp list --url https://staging.example.com

docs.title: SSH Config Integration
docs.text:
You can reference ~/.ssh/config hosts:

servers:
  my-server:
    ssh_host: my-alias  # Uses ~/.ssh/config settings
    wp_path: /var/www/wordpress

Your ~/.ssh/config: 

Host my-alias
    HostName example.com
    User admin
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Override config with environment variables:

export WP_HOSTNAME=example.com
export WP_SSH_USER=admin
export WP_PATH=/var/www/wordpress
export WP_PHP_BIN=/usr/bin/php
export WP_CLI_BIN=/usr/local/bin/wp

docs.title: Plesk Servers
docs.text:
For Plesk-hosted WordPress:

servers:
  plesk-site:
    hostname: server.example.com
    username: subscription_user
    key_file: ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
    wp_path: /var/www/vhosts/example.com/httpdocs
    php_bin: /opt/plesk/php/8.3/bin/php
    wp_cli: /usr/local/bin/wp

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.9+
  • SSH access to your WordPress server (for SSH transport)
  • kubectl configured (for Kubernetes transport)
  • WP-CLI installed on the remote server

docs.title: Install PraisonAIWP
docs.text:
pipuvpipx (recommended for CLI)From source 
pip install praisonaiwp

uv pip install praisonaiwp

pipx install praisonaiwp

git clone https://github.com/MervinPraison/praisonaiwp.git
cd praisonaiwp
pip install -e .

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text: praisonaiwp --version

docs.title: Install WP-CLI on Remote Server
docs.text:
If WP-CLI is not installed on your WordPress server:

# Download WP-CLI
curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/wp-cli/builds/gh-pages/phar/wp-cli.phar

# Make executable
chmod +x wp-cli.phar

# Move to path
sudo mv wp-cli.phar /usr/local/bin/wp

# Verify
wp --info

docs.title: Kubernetes Setup
docs.text: PraisonAIWP supports Kubernetes-hosted WordPress installations via kubectl exec.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• kubectl installed and configured
  • Access to the Kubernetes cluster running WordPress
  • WordPress pod accessible via kubectl exec

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Add a Kubernetes server to your config:

servers:
  my-k8s-site:
    website: https://my-k8s-site.example.com
    description: "WordPress on Kubernetes"

    # Transport type
    transport: kubernetes

    # Pod selection (choose one)
    pod_selector: app=wordpress      # Label selector
    # OR
    pod_name: wordpress-pod-abc123   # Specific pod name

    # Kubernetes settings
    namespace: default               # Namespace (default: default)
    container: wordpress             # Container name (if multi-container pod)
    context: my-cluster              # kubectl context (optional)

    # WordPress paths
    wp_path: /var/www/html
    php_bin: /usr/local/bin/php
    wp_cli: wp

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
Option Required Description transport Yes Set to kubernetes or k8s pod_selector Yes* Label selector to find pod pod_name Yes* Specific pod name namespace No Kubernetes namespace (default: default) container No Container name for multi-container pods context No kubectl context to use wp_path Yes WordPress path inside container php_bin No PHP binary path (default: php) wp_cli No WP-CLI path (default: wp)

*Either pod_selector or pod_name is required.

docs.title: Example: WordPress on AKS
docs.text:
servers:
  praison-ai:
    website: https://praison.ai
    description: "PraisonAI website on AKS"
    transport: kubernetes
    pod_selector: app=php-nginx
    namespace: default
    container: wb-php
    wp_path: /var/www/pa/web
    php_bin: /usr/local/bin/php
    wp_cli: wp

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# List posts
praisonaiwp --server praison-ai list

# Create a post
praisonaiwp --server praison-ai create "My Post" --content "<p>Hello!</p>"

# Check connection
praisonaiwp --server praison-ai help

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
The Kubernetes transport uses:

  1. Pod Resolution: If pod_selector is used, finds a running pod matching the labels
  2. Command Execution: Uses kubectl exec to run WP-CLI commands
  3. File Transfer: Uses kubectl cp for file uploads/downloads
flowchart LR
    A[PraisonAIWP] --> B[kubectl exec]
    B --> C[WordPress Pod]
    C --> D[WP-CLI]
    D --> E[WordPress]

docs.title: Cannot find pod
docs.text:
Error: No running pods found with selector: app=wordpress

Check your pod selector: 

kubectl get pods -l app=wordpress -n default

docs.title: Permission denied
docs.text:
Ensure your kubectl context has permissions: 

kubectl auth can-i exec pods -n default

docs.title: Container not found
docs.text:
If your pod has multiple containers, specify the container name: 

container: wordpress

List containers in a pod: 

kubectl get pod POD_NAME -o jsonpath='{.spec.containers[*].name}'

docs.title: WP-CLI not found
docs.text:
Install WP-CLI in your container or specify the correct path: 

wp_cli: /usr/local/bin/wp
# OR if using wp as a script
wp_cli: /var/www/html/wp

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get started with PraisonAIWP in 5 minutes.

docs.title: 1. Configure Your Server
docs.text:
Initialize the configuration:

praisonaiwp init

This creates ~/.praisonaiwp/config.yaml. Edit it with your server details:

default_server: my-server
servers:
  my-server:
    hostname: example.com
    username: admin
    key_file: ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
    wp_path: /var/www/wordpress
    php_bin: /usr/bin/php
    wp_cli: /usr/local/bin/wp

docs.title: 2. Test Connection
docs.text:
praisonaiwp list --limit 5

If successful, you'll see your WordPress posts listed.

docs.title: 3. Create Your First Post
docs.text:
praisonaiwp create "My First Post" \
  --content "<h2>Hello World</h2><p>This is my first post created with PraisonAIWP!</p>" \
  --status publish

HTML Auto-Conversion

HTML content is automatically converted to Gutenberg blocks. You don't need to write raw block markup!

docs.title: 4. List Posts
docs.text:
# List all published posts
praisonaiwp list --status publish

# List pages
praisonaiwp list --type page

# JSON output for scripting
praisonaiwp --json list --limit 10

docs.title: 5. Update a Post
docs.text:
# Update post title
praisonaiwp update 123 --post-title "Updated Title"

# Update post content
praisonaiwp update 123 --post-content "<p>New content here</p>"

docs.title: 6. Search for Content
docs.text:
# Find posts containing a keyword
praisonaiwp find "wordpress"
